 Then there's Ernst Mayr, speaking in 1942 about how the improvement of complex structures like the eye via random mutation strained credulity. It's fascinating stuff. I have to watch myself, though: it's easy to fall into the same trap as Archangel and start inventing conspiracies, start demonising 'the enemy'. I've done it already in this thread:
 
So what we have here is a lie, based on a distortion, which is itself a fallback position from a fallback position from a fallback position from an evidence-free made-up graph about the magnetic age of the earth. And creationists say the truth is constant... 

 It's so darn easy and tempting to think like that, to take the end result of many stages of investigation, interpretation, communication - and treat it as the product of one consciousness, some coherent unit labelled 'creationists'. But that's excessive and unfair.
 
 What permits these notions to thrive and solidify are the little things: the counterargument not mentioned when relating a debate to a friend, the detail omitted by someone who does not appreciate its significance - even the speed at which 'acceptable' interpretations diffuse through a community compared to less acceptable ones. The extended creationist community - and I stress extended, loose, casual, informal, happenstance - is really just a big filter.
 
 The creationist 'side' does have one major inherent advantage over science: it has no real need to filter obsolete arguments out of the system. The 'truth' they have to preserve lies outside the shifting justifications used to shore it up, whereas most of the accumulated value of science lies in the theories, not the conclusions. It's hard to think of a single creationist justification, no matter how hackneyed, or how thoroughly and repeatedly debunked, or even disowned by sites like AiG, that isn't still in circulation, clogging up minds and forums alike. Continents don't move. The earth wouldn't still be magnetic if it was as old as they say. They've found dinosaur bones with soft tissue inside.
 
 Science has to work with what it has, regardless of whether it's counterintuitive, difficult to follow, or requires a bit of lateral thinking. Creationism on the other hand gets all the good soundbites: "What use is half an eye?" "If we're descended from chimps, why are there still chimps?" "You can't have a watch without a watchmaker, and a living thing is much more complicated than a watch". You don't have to think to agree with rhetoric like that, and if all you need to do to carry on believing exactly what mummy and daddy and the big serious man in church taught you is not think, well... it's certainly tempting. It's encouraging, though, how few creationists choose to remain satisfied with that level of rationalisation.
 
 The more I think about it, the more remarkable it seems that reason prevails as often as it does. Perhaps it's because science produces all the results. Creationism doesn't really achieve anything; it's a strident and vigorous engine devoted to the principle of staying where you are. Adherents get a continual payoff, the reaffirmation that they're right, but not much else. Science gets all the cool new toys, makes sick people better - and predicts things correctly, which is something we get an instinctive buzz out of. Watch any baby learning 'boo' and you can see it.
